Title:
Discovery of a Cryptic Species in Paris yunnanensis
(Melanthiaceae) Using Complete Plastomes and Ribosomal DNA Sequences as
Ultra-barcodes
Keywords:
conservation, cryptic species, DNA barcoding, Paris
yunnanensis, taxonomy
Abstract:
Ultra-barcoding is a technique using whole plastomes and
nuclear ribosomal DNA sequences for species identification. However,
practical application of this technique for discovery of cryptic and
novel species is still absent from literatures. Paris yunnanensis is a
medicinal plant of economic importance for the pharmaceutical industry.
Although the introduction, domestication, cultivation, and propagation
of the species have been extensively studied in recent years, its
taxonomy has received very little attention. To resolve long-standing
taxonomic disputes regarding this species, we de novo sequenced the
complete plastomes and nuclear ribosomal DNA regions from 22 P.
yunnanensis accessions. Ultra-barcoding analyse s suggest that P.
yunnanensis as currently circumscribed is made up of two distinct
genetic lineages, corresponding to the two phenotypes (“typical” and
“high stem” form) identified early in our study. With distinct
morphologies and distribution, the “high stem” form should be recognized
as an undescribed species. Moreover, the ultra-barcoding data do not
support treatment of P. yunnanensis as a conspecific variety under Paris
polyphylla. These results highlight the great potential of
ultra-barcoding as an effective tool for species identification and
discovery in taxonomically difficult plant taxa, and have implications
for the conservation and management of P. yunnanensis germplasm.
